plant_concentrations.References: (1) Qiu X, Hites RA; Environ Sci Technol 42: 31-6 (2008) (2) Salamova A, Hites RA; Environ Sci Technol 47: 349-54 (2013) (3) Tian M et al; Environ Sci Technol 46: 2708-14 (2012)
plant_concentrations.Value: Decabromodiphenyl ethane, measured in pine tree bark samples collected the autumn of 2006 from 26 US locations (Indiana, Massachusetts, Maryland, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia) was found at not detected to 0.73 ng/g bark(1). Decabromodiphenyl ethane was not detected in tree bark from 9 of 12 locations around the world (Birkenes, Norway; Bukit Kototabang, Indonesia; Cape Grim, Tasmania; De Aar, South Africa; Dhulikhel, Nepal; Malin Head, Ireland; Reykjavik, Iceland; Tula, American Samoa, US; Whistler, BC, Canada) but was detected at 6.63, 1.39 and 3.92 ng/g lipid in tree bark from Toronto, and Frasardale, ON, Canada, and Kosetice, Czech Republic, respectively(2). In eucalyptus (Eucalyptus spp) leaves and Masson pine (Pinus massoniana) needles of trees growing in an e-waste site in China, decabromodiphenyl ethane was detected at 9.14-35.6 and 11.2-42.3 ng/g dry weight, respectively, samples were collected Jul 2007 to Jun 2008(3).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Venier M, Hites RA; Environ Sci Technol 45: 4602-8 (2011) (2) Keller JM et al; Environ Sci Technol 48: 7807-16 (2014) (3) de la Torre A et al; Environ Sci Technol 46: 12364-72 (2012) (4) McKinney MA et al; Environ Int 37: 365-74 (2011) (5) Baron E et al; Environ Sci Technol 49: 9073-83 (2015) (6) Hong B et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 94: 12-6 (2015)
animal_concentrations.Value: Decabromodiphenyl ethane was not detected in serum samples collected from 17 dogs in Bloomington, IN(1). Serum samples collected 2011-2012 from green turtles (Chelonia mydas) in the Hawaiian Islands did not contain decabromodiphenyl ethane (detection limit 17 pg/g wet weight)(2). Reported concentrations of decabromodiphenyl ethane were not detected to 14.9 ng/g lipid weight in the liver of 20 franciscana dolphin (Pontoporia blainvillei), collected along the Brazilian coast between 1994 and 2008(3). Decabromodiphenyl ethane was not detected in adipose tissue from 11 circumpolar polar bear (Ursus maritimus) sub-populations in 2005-2008 spanning Alaska east to Svalbard(4). Decabromodiphenyl ethane was not detected (detection limit 1.06 ng/g lipid) in the blubber and brain of five species of stranded dolphins (Delphinus delphis, Stenella coureloalba, Globicephala melas, Grampus griseus, Tursiops truncatus) collected on the Alboran Sea coastline between 2004 and 2011(5). Decabromodiphenyl ethane was detected in adult tissues, neonates and eggs of captive Chinese alligators (Alligator sinensis) at 4.74-192, 0.24-1.94 and 0.01-0.51 ng/g lipid weight, respectively(6).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Hu G-C et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 4704-9 (2008)
animal_concentrations.Value: Tissue samples were collected and analyzed for decabromodiphenyl ethane from eight giant panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca) in Dec 2006 from the Beijing Zoo and from eight red panda (Ailurus fulgens) in Nov 2006 from the Chongqing Zoo(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Gauthier LT, Letcher RJ; Chemosphere 75: 115-20 (2009) (2) Gentes M-L et al; Environ Sci Technol 46: 9735-44 (2012) (3) Sun YX et al; Environ Pollut 162: 381-8 (2012) (4) Mo L et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 31: 2153-8 (2012)
animal_concentrations.Value: Decabromodiphenyl ethane was not detected in herring gull eggs (Larus argentatus), collected fifteen years (1982-2006) from colonies at Toronto Harbor (Lake Ontario) and Channel Shelter Island (Lake Huron)(1). At other locations, decabromodiphenyl was detected at 1.3 ng/g wet weight (ww) in 1996 at a colony in Niagra River (above the falls), at 10, 11 and 104 ng/g ww in 1999, 2001 and 2004 at Gull Island (Lake Michigan), at 3.2 ng/g ww in 2003 at Fighting Island (Detroit River), at 11, 288 and 44 ng/g ww in 2004, 2005 and 2006 at Chantry Island (Lake Huron) and 4.3 and 9.3 ng/g ww in 2005 and 2006 at Agawa Rocks (Lake Superior)(1). Decabromodiphenyl ethane was not detected (detection limit 0.07 ng/g wet weight) in the plasma or liver of ring-billed gulls (Larus delawarensis) collected Apr-Jun 2010 from the St Lawrence River, downstream of Montreal, Canada(2). In light-vented bulbul (Pycnonotus sinensis), long-tailed shrike (Lanius schach) and oriental magpie-robin (Copsychus saularis) collected from 7 sampling sites in South China, decabromodiphenyl ethane levels were not detected to 130 ng/g lipid weight(3). The median concentration of decabromodiphenyl ethane in kingfishers (Alcedo atthis) collected from an e-waste recycling site in South China was reported as 12 ng/g lipid weight(4).
River Delta, Chnia collected 2010 to 2012 were reported(1).

animal_concentrations.Value: Concentrations of decabromodiphenyl ethane in bird eggs collected May 2008 from the Yellow River Delta, North China were reported(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Munschy C et al; Sci Total Environ 409: 4618-27 (2011)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Decabromodiphenyl ethane was measured in muscle and liver from common sole (Solea solea L) collected 2007-2009 from locations along the French English Channel and Atlantic Coast(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Yang R et al; Environ Sci Technol 46: 3119-26 (2012) (2) La Guardia MJ et al; Environ Sci Technol 46: 5798-805 (2012) (3) Kierkegaard A et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 3247-53 (2004) (4) Ricklund N et al; Environ Sci Technol 44: 1987-91 (2010) (5) Nyholm JR et al; Sci Total Environ 443: 307-14 (2013) (6) Zhu B et al; Chemosphere 93: 555-60 (2013) (7) La Guardia MJ et al; Environ Sci Technol 47: 9643-50 (2013)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: The concentration of decabromodiphenyl ethane was reported as 0.13-0.75, 0.87-8.3, 1.6-2.5, 0.19-0.44 and 2.7-3.8 ng/g dry weight in surface sediment samples collected Aug 1-25, 2007 from Lakes Superior, Michigan, Huron, Erie and Ontario, respectively(1). Decabromodiphenyl ethane was not detected in sediment samples collected Jul 2009 downstream from a textile manufacturing outfall on the Yadkin River in North Carolina(2).  Decabromodiphenyl ethane was detected at 24 ng/g dry weight in a sediment sample collected in 2001 from Western Scheldt, The Netherlands(3). Sediment collected in 2007 from 11 lakes in Sweden contained decabromodiphenyl ethane at 0.23-11 ng/g dry weight; in 2008, marine sediment samples were collected at seven sites on a transect from Stockholm-Stockholm archipelago, Sweden, decabromodiphenyl ethane was detected at 0.18-11 ng/g dry weight(4). In sediment samples collected in 2009 from Loselva River, Norway, decabromodiphenyl ethane was detected at 1.2 ng/g dry weight(5). Sediment samples collected the summer of 2011 from the Lingjiang, Oujiang and Qiantang Rivers, located in the Yangtze River Delta contained 2.42-19.0 ng/g dry weight of decabromodiphenyl ethane; it was detected in 46% of samples from the East China Sea at <0.176-1.57 ng/g dry weight(6). In 28 of 45 sediment samples collected in Aug 2011 from Durban Bay and 13 rivers in the eThekwini metropolitan municipality, South Africa, decabromodiphenyl ethane was detected at 0.6-1840 ng/g dry weight(7).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Zhu Z-C et al; Sci Total Environ 481: 47-54 (2014) (2) Lin Y et al; Environ Sci Pollut Res Int 22: 13319-27 (2015) (3) Drage DS et al; Chemosphere 148: 195-203 (2016)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Decabromodiphenyl ethane was detected in 38 soil samples collected May 2008 from Shouguang, China at 12.0-344 ng/g(1). In soil samples collected from 87 sites in North China, decabromodiphenyl ethane was reported at undetectable to 1612 ng/g, the highest concentration was found in Shandong(2). Decabromodiphenyl ethane was detected at <0.0059-0.24 ng/g dry weight in soil samples collected Jan 2013 from eight sites located along a transect in England (Worcester, Droitwich, Bromsgrove, Bournville, Edgbason, Digbeth, Sutton Coldfield, Tamworth)(3).
